Message.Title: In a stunning twist, right wing extremist group AL-JO-BAAB was hired as part of the "Tech Surge" to fix healthcare.gov
Message.Msg: CGI was able to track down the rag tag boys from Odessa in their junkyard hideaway. Feeling they were in for a firefight, Al, Jo and Baab dug in and were loaded and ready to let fly with some Texas justice. But CGI wasn't there to fight. "Cmon out guys we aren't cops we're the website dudes you've been messing with. We have lots of money and we need sharp guys like you. We need help bad. We'll pay you $18.50 an hour and a six pack for every bug you fix." Well the boys couldn't hardly believe their ears. "How do we know you ain't lyin like that Obama fella?" There was some commotion and then, a response. "To show you we mean what we say, here is a little advance". They tossed a rock wrapped with three 20 dollar bills through the window. They quickly did the math and realized that meant a bill for each of them and they were hooked. "You just make sure it's Bud and not that Coors #$%$ water and you got yerself some hackers". Thus began the unlikely alliance between a group of r*dneck hackers from Texas and a bunch of IT Hosers from Canada working on the future of healthcare in America. What a country.

Message.Title: October 29, 2013 7:18 AM Obamacare: More than 2 million people getting booted from existing health insurance plans
Message.Msg: (CBS News) CBS News has learned more than two million Americans have been told they cannot renew their current insurance policies -- more than triple the number of people said to be buying insurance under the new Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare. There have been estimates about hundreds of thousands of people losing coverage, CBS News' Jan Crawford reported on "CBS This Morning." CBS News has reached out to insurance companies across the country to determine some of the real numbers -- and this is just the tip of the iceberg, Crawford said. The people who are opening the letters are shocked to learn they can't keep their insurance policies despite President Obama's assurances to the contrary. The White House is on the defensive trying to explain it, after Mr. Obama repeatedly said, "If you like your doctor or health care plan, you can keep it." White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said, "What the president said and what everybody said all along is that there are going to be changes brought about by the Affordable Care Act to create minimum standards of coverage." It's an unexpected reality of Obamacare being told through anecdotes in local papers and on social media. But the hard numbers reveal the evidence is far more than anecdotal. CBS News has confirmed with insurance companies across the country that more than two million people are getting notices they no longer can keep their existing plans. In California, there are 279,000; in Michigan, 140,000; Florida, 300,000; and in New Jersey, 800,000. And those numbers are certain to go even higher. Some companies who tell CBS News they've sent letters won't say how many. Industry experts like Larry Levitt, of the Kaiser Family Foundation, say the insurance companies have no choice. "What we're seeing now is reality coming into play," he said. Obamacare forces them to drop many of their plans that don't meet the law's 10 minimum standards, including maternity care, emergency visits, mental healt

Topic.Title: October 29, 2013 7:18 AM Obamacare: More than 2 million people getting booted from existing health insurance plans

Message.Msg: That means consumers have to sign on to new plans even if they don't want or need the more generous coverage. Industry experts say about half the people getting the letters will pay more -- and half will pay less, thanks to taxpayer subsidies. Levitt said, "The winners outnumber the losers here, but because of all the website problems, it's hard to find out who the winners are because they don't even know it themselves." And for the people who've gotten the letters, the broken website is a real problem, Crawford added on "CTM." They don't know what to do. They don't know if they get subsidies. And then there are others getting the letters who have very good insurance but are being told they can't keep it. Industry experts CBS News talked to say for everyone, the best bet is to just call their insurance companies to get the information.

Haven't you figured out that I can easily recognize and distinguish different styles and voices from each other, never mind doing a fair job of imitating and parodying them? At least have the decency to put quotations around someone else's words and thoughts, with some attribution and citations! In the world of publishing, the ugliest word is 'plagiarism'. You, sir, are proving yourself to be both a plagiarist AND a ball-smuggler. You gave some lip service to the notion of nonpartisanship last week, and then turn right around and go back to partisan fecal flinging. Wrap your lips around something ELSE, and begone with you. Message.Title: The Republican Creed
Message.Msg: You see I have a $118,500 BMW that has a custom $19,000 audio system. The installer told me it was the best system he's ever heard. I was driving last weekend when another BMW pulled up beside me at a traffic light. It was one of the cheaper, less than $70,000 BMW's driven by and elderly man. He had his window down and was waving at me. I lowered my window and he said, 'Good day, very nice car you have there.' I started laughing, pointed at the Rolex I had draped over the steering wheel, gave him the finger and sped off. Just because someone is driving a car that has the BMW logo doesn't mean that they are in the same economic class as me. My car is clearly more special and much more expensive. It's really embarrassing when I see democrats like that trying to play the part. Not impressive at all. Oh by the way, I'll be going over to Starbucks and wearing my new $1100 Chanel sweater. Do you think the manager will be impressed?

Message.Title: Stock Set to Rally 45% Next Week!
Message.Msg: Agria (GRO) is set to rally 45% from $1.30 to $1.88 over the next 3-5 trading days. GRO's 80.81% owned Agria Asia subsidiary owns 379.1mm shares of PGG Wrightson (PGW.NZ), New Zealand's largest agriculture company, which brokeout last night by rising $0.02 to NZ$0.41 per share. GRO's PGW shares are now worth $104.12 million and GRO has 55.38 million shares outstanding, which means GRO is about to rise to $1.88. A few weeks ago when PGW was only $0.38, GRO's stake in PGW was worth $1.74 per share and GRO rallied from $1.12 to $1.74 for a gain of 55% in just two weeks. Afterwards, GRO fell back down to $1.30 due to one major investor cashing out for personal reasons unrelated to the company. GRO bounced strongly yesterday off of its 50-day moving average of $1.25 and with the seller now 95% gone and PGW rising last night to NZ$0.41 on the New Zealand Exchange, GRO is about to rally by 45% to $1.88 between now and this time next week! Take advantage of any GRO shares available here it is the biggest blessing of our lifetimes! GRO is artificially low and must rise to $1.88 based on the rising value of its PGW shares! For every 1 penny PGW rises, GRO's stake in the company increases in value by $0.0459 per share! Whatever price PGW trades at, GRO's proper value is a share price that is 4.59X higher! (We own 550,000 shares of GRO and don't intend to sell until GRO is trading at MUCH higher prices.)

Message.Title: It just keeps getting better :)
Message.Msg: Why Obamacare could raise your premiums at work By Scott Cohn | CNBC – 6 hours ago The estimated 149 million Americans under age 65 who get their health insurance through their employers could be the next group to feel the impact of the Affordable Care Act. Open enrollment for 2014 is about to begin at thousands of companies, and many employers are blaming Obamacare -at least in part-for cost increases they are passing on to their workers. Employees' costs are expected to rise 5 to 7 percent next year, according to early estimates. Those annual increases have been a fixture for years. But in some 2014 open enrollment documents reviewed by CNBC, companies are specifically citing the law as a factor in next year's pricing.

Message.Title: BofA Longs. Jury deliberated 20 minutes!!
Message.Msg: 20 whole minutes in the jury room before rendering a verdict. If you think that's not a sign for other litigants, you're either dumb or stupid. BofA had 9 civil litigation lawyers working on the case. Billable hours totaled $3.4 million dollars for the case. The jury deliberated 20 minutes before announcing "guilty". Thye had supposedly the cream of the crop civil lawyers. The best minds in the country defending this case. 20 whole minutes it took them to vote guilty. If that doesn't send a message to others about suing, nothing will. I expect a floodgate of lawsuits that are seemingly won with ease.

Especially difficult next few months. Own stock long term 15-17 range, down to 5-7 range, then again in the 8's. Recently sold in the money calls and took a heavier then normal short term out of money put trade. Long term BAC will see $20 once the heavy north wind calms. But thanks for the weather check. Always good to be looking ahead

Topic.Title: So how goes the al bundy kyle dube economics and social and medical development conference?

Message.Msg: Your are quite right in your thematic apperceptive assessment of my current state....I is fried from late socks nights, chafing at shipboard life (not a comfortable or familiar environment for a natural-born treetop flyer), frustrated by non-critical thinkers and non-performing 'organizing committees' and blights on the roses of modern womanhood and comfort women who provide no comfort and are not even women and yes, to be quite honest as dear friends must be with one another, a bit bored with your repetitive musings and philosophical questions that have no utility to the pursuit of the easy big buck within easy reach.....really, a few half-hearted pinkie-lifts from you and/or viewer at this critical juncture will have us all wallowing in piles of duh-mass and corporate cash in time to blow it like drunken sailors on R&R in Bangkok before Christmas (see, nautical rather than aeronautical similes, this shipboard life is killing me and polluting my normally gin-clear stream of consciousness). I would apologize if the process did not amount to ripping my pancreas from its moorings (dammit!) while army ants crawl up my nose and steel machine screws are threaded into my eyeballs......GENIUS IS PAIN, I TELL YOU! AND I'VE ALWAYS BEEN A FOOKIN' GENIUS, KNOWN IT SINCE MY MOTHER PULLED HER NIPPLE AWAY AND TRYED DROWNING ME IN FOOKIN' GERBER FORMULA AND MADE ME WEAR LITTLE LORD FAUNTLEROY KNICKERS AND THOSE TODDLER SUSPENDERS AND THAT SCHMUCK BOWTIE AND BUCKLETOP BUSTER BROWNS..... wait, I actually liked the shoes, wouldn't wear anything else....look, I need a rest, and you sure don't. ROTFPM my white stovepipe Levis and staining my cordovan penny loafers. Yours in perennial mental health and stability, - Frankie Thadwallader Kilbyrne.
